results.title: Still pictures on television
results.creator_credit: Centre for Educational Television Overseas and Lawrie Lawler
results.brief_description: Demonstrates techniques of using still photographs and art work in television production, showing occasions where they are effective. Includes series of photographs and drawings to compress time and concludes with an example.

results.title: Still on the same way (A)
results.creator_credit: Orcalia Productions, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Graham Cavanagh
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The Australian Aboriginals connection to the land and to his sacred sites has often been misunderstood by white Australia. With the help of the Aborigines from Gilwi Community, near Timber Creek, Northern Territory, Bob Ellis of the Sacred Sites Authority and spokesmen from the Northern Land Council, this program clearly explains what sacred sites are, the aboriginal concept of land tenure and how development by white Australia is managed in the Northern Territory through a mandatory consultation process, set down in the Aboriginal Land Rights Act.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Orcalia Productions, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Graham Cavanagh

results.title: Still Life
results.brief_description: This film starts out appearing to be an art documentary about a Scottish painter Lawrence Angus Mc Coney. It uses artwork, animation and photographic effects to give a vivid sense of the artist’s life. ‘Still Life’ is a humorous send up of art criticism but it also sets out to express what it feels like to be an artist. Narrated by Gary Bond.

results.title: Still killing us softly
results.creator_credit: Cambridge Documentary Films and Margaret Margaret Lazarus
results.brief_description: In this program, Jean Kilbourne examines images in advertising. She explores the relationship of media images to actual problems in society, such as the channelling of men and women into traditional roles and occupations, economic discrimination against women, the sexual abuse of children, rape and other forms of violence, pornography, sexual harassment, teenage pregnancy and eating disorders.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cambridge Documentary Films and Margaret Margaret Lazarus

results.title: Still in one piece anyway
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Ian McLaren, Rex Tasker and Bruce Mackay
results.brief_description: The film follows the Takaoka Maru, an enormous super-tanker carrying 1.5 million barrels of oil, as it ponderously winds its way through the Canso Strait to the oil refinery at Chedabucto Bay. It captures the intricate drama of docking and unloading the amount of oil Canada consumes in one day. Through an artful mixture of special sound effects, expressive photography, music and commentary, the film speaks both in awe, and in fear, of this creature of man’s making. A powerful documentary of a most unusual sort. Photographed by Les Krizsan and Barry Perles. Edited by Jy Chiperzak and Bruce Mackay. Sound by Raymond Marcoux and Bernie Bordeleau
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Ian McLaren, Rex Tasker and Bruce Mackay

results.title: Still flying
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Robert Stephenson
results.brief_description: Award winning animated short about an old air force veteran who reminisces about the war years. Mostly a claymation work, Stephenson uses hand-drawn 2D animation to indicate the flashbacks experienced by the the veteran whilst supping on his beer at his local pub. The veteren, who struggles to find meaning in his old age, draws on his experiences of the past in a heady mix of booze and disillusionment in an attempt to make sense of his life. Voices: Graeme Jackson, Andrea Lang.
